title: Quiz 4: Medical-Surgical Nursing (Jan 2024 FQE)
topicName: Medical Surgical Nursing FQE PastPapers Collection
description: Final Qualifying Examination from January 2024 covering neurosurgery, burns, respiratory conditions, and renal care.

questions.question: A nursing measure that is indicated to reduce the potential for seizures and increased intracranial pressure in a patient with bacterial meningitis is:

options.text: Administering codeine for relief of head and neck pain
Keeping the room darkened and quiet to minimize environmental stimuli
Maintaining the patient on a strict bed rest with the head of bed slightly elevated

questions.explanation: Patients with meningitis have meningeal irritation (photophobia, phonophobia). Environmental stimuli (bright lights, noise) can lower the seizure threshold and increase ICP. Reducing stimuli is a key seizure precaution.
questions.hint: Think about environmental triggers for seizures.

questions.question: You are preparing to administer an antibiotic to a patient with impetigo. The culture report on the infection will indicate infection of:
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism for impetigo. Group A Streptococcus is also a cause but Staph is statistically more common in non-bullous impetigo.
questions.hint: This organism is the most common cause of skin infections like boils and impetigo.

questions.question: The physician orders heparin, 7,500 units, to be administered subcutaneously every 6 hours. The vial reads 10,000 units per milliliter. How much heparin should be anticipated for each dose?
questions.explanation: Calculation: 7,500 units / 10,000 units/ml = 0.75 ml, which is equivalent to ¾ ml.
questions.hint: Divide the ordered dose by the concentration on hand.

questions.question: The nursing observation that points to complications of intestinal obstruction following exploratory laparotomy within the 1st 24 hours would be:

options.text: Protruding soft abdomen with frequent diarrhea
Minimal bowel sounds in all four quadrants
Distended abdomen with complaints of pain

questions.explanation: Post-operative ileus or mechanical obstruction manifests as abdominal distension and pain. Minimal bowel sounds are expected in the first 24 hours (paralytic ileus). Frequent diarrhea is unlikely with obstruction.
questions.hint: Look for signs of pressure buildup and discomfort.

questions.question: A client has just had a total knee replacement for severe osteoarthritis. You will suspect possible nerve damage if you observed:
questions.explanation: The peroneal nerve is at risk during knee surgery. Damage manifests as numbness, tingling (paresthesia), or inability to dorsiflex the foot (foot drop). Pain is expected post-op.
questions.hint: Nerve damage affects sensation and motor function, not just pain sensation.

questions.question: One of the following would lead you to suspect that a patient with fracture of the right femur may be developing a fat embolus?

options.text: Muscle spasms in the right thigh

questions.explanation: The classic triad of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) involves respiratory distress (hypoxemia, ARDS), neurological changes, and a petechial rash.
questions.hint: Fat globules from the marrow travel to the lungs first.

questions.question: During treatment of burns, one feature to look out for as a cause of contractures would be:
questions.explanation: Contractures occur when the burn scar matures and shortens due to hypertrophic scarring (excessive collagen/fibrous tissue), pulling surrounding skin tight.
questions.hint: Think about what scar tissue is made of.

questions.question: You find the skin of the arm of a burn patient white and hard. It is inelastic and insensitive to pressure. You will classify the burn as:
questions.explanation: Full-thickness burns (3rd degree) are characterized by a waxy white, leathery, hard appearance (eschar) and are painless because nerve endings are destroyed.
questions.hint: The destruction of nerve endings makes this burn painless.

questions.question: As a postpartum nurse providing instructions to a mother of a newborn infant with hyperbilirubinemia and who is being breastfed, which would be the appropriate instruction to the mother?

options.text: Switch to bottle-feeding the baby for 2 weeks
Stop the breastfeeding and switch to bottle-feeding permanently
Feed the newborn infant less frequently

questions.explanation: Frequent feeding promotes regular bowel movements, which helps eliminate bilirubin in the stool.
questions.hint: Bilirubin is excreted through stool; more food equals more stool.

questions.question: One of the major disadvantages of peritoneal dialysis to look out for is:

options.text: Hypotension is a constant problem because of constant fluid removal
Blood loss can be extensive because of the use of heparin to keep the catheter patent
High concentration of dialysate necessary for ultrafiltration cause carbohydrate and lipid abnormalities
Solutes are removed more rapidly from the blood than from the central nervous system, causing disequilibrium syndrome

questions.explanation: Peritoneal dialysate contains high concentrations of glucose (dextrose), which can be absorbed, leading to hyperglycemia and lipid abnormalities. Disequilibrium syndrome is a risk of Hemodialysis.
questions.hint: The dialysis fluid is sugar-based.

questions.question: The nursing observation that indicates that a male client with a kidney stone is experiencing renal colic would be:

options.text: Severe flank pain radiating toward the testicles
Hematuria and severe burning on urination

questions.explanation: Classic renal colic presents as sudden, severe flank pain that radiates anteriorly and downward to the groin or testicles as the stone moves down the ureter.
questions.hint: The pain follows the path of the ureter downwards.

questions.question: The main predisposing factors of lung cancer include:

options.text: Cold weather, smoking, exposure to radiation, poor dietary habits
Smoking, poor dietary habits exposure to radiation, exposure to coal dust
Warm weather, exposure to radiation, poor dietary habits, exposure to coal dust
Smoking, exposure to radiation, exposure to coal dust, alcoholism

questions.explanation: Cigarette smoking is the primary risk factor. Occupational exposures (asbestos, coal dust, radiation) are also significant.
questions.hint: Focus on inhaled carcinogens.

questions.question: Match the respiratory condition with its description:

pairs.right: Destructive changes in alveolar walls and enlargement of air spaces
Hypersecretion of mucus with recurrent cough

questions.explanation: Emphysema involves structural destruction of alveoli (air trapping), while Bronchitis involves inflammation and excessive mucus production.
questions.hint: One is about destruction of walls, the other is about mucus.

questions.question: Alice is rushed to the emergency department during an acute, severe prolonged asthma attack and is unresponsive to usual treatment. This condition is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Status asthmaticus is a severe, life-threatening asthma attack that is refractory to standard bronchodilator therapy.
questions.hint: It implies a persistent state.

questions.question: A client diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus has been ordered a course of prednisone for her severe arthritic pain. An expected change that requires close monitoring is:
questions.explanation: Corticosteroids like Prednisone induce gluconeogenesis and increase insulin resistance, leading to hyperglycemia.
questions.hint: Steroids raise sugar levels.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding Glaucoma are TRUE? (Select all that apply)

options.text: It is caused by impaired drainage of aqueous humour
It is associated with elevated intracranial pressure

questions.explanation: Glaucoma is caused by impaired drainage of aqueous humor leading to elevated INTRAOCULAR pressure, not intracranial pressure.
questions.hint: Focus on the pressure within the eye vs the brain.

questions.question: Microorganisms that are Gram negative bacilli include:
questions.explanation: E. coli, Salmonella, and Shigella are Gram-negative rods. Staphylococcus and Streptococcus are Gram-positive cocci.
questions.hint: Staph and Strep are positive; enteric gut bacteria are often negative.

questions.question: To open the airway of an adult suspected to have sustained neck and back injury, you will apply jaw thrust by placing:

options.text: The hand on the person's forehead and using the other hand, gently lifting the chin
A soft pillow under the neck, then lifting the jaw upwards
The fingers under the angle of the jaw on both sides, then lifting the jaw upwards
The hand on the person's forehead and applying a little pressure to achieve the tilt

questions.explanation: The Jaw Thrust maneuver lifts the mandible without tilting the head, protecting the cervical spine in trauma patients.
questions.hint: Avoid moving the neck.

questions.question: To ensure that learners have understood the concept of voluntary respiration, the teacher would expect them to indicate that it is controlled via:
questions.explanation: Voluntary control (conscious decision to breathe) originates in the cerebral cortex. Automatic control is in the brainstem.
questions.hint: Where does conscious thought originate?

questions.question: You are evaluating a client's fluid intake and output record. What should be the relationship between fluid intake and urine output?

options.text: Fluid intake should double the urine output.
Fluid intake should approximately equal to the urine output.
Fluid intake should be half the urine output.
Fluid intake should be inversely proportional to the urine output.

questions.explanation: In a healthy state, fluid intake correlates closely with total output. Since urine is the main measurable output, they should be approximately equal (intake usually slightly higher to cover insensible loss).
questions.hint: Balance is key.

questions.question: The health message that should be shared to a patient who has suffered myocardial infarction include:

options.text: Identification and modification of all risk factors
Reporting to heath care providers if extremely fatigued
Eating low salt but fluid-free diet

questions.explanation: Secondary prevention (preventing recurrence) depends on modifying risk factors like diet, smoking, and lifestyle.
questions.hint: Think about long-term prevention.

questions.question: Health assessment includes nursing audit. The retrospective audit is done based on:
questions.explanation: Retrospective audit looks back at care already provided, primarily by reviewing the patient's clinical records after discharge.
questions.hint: Retrospective means 'looking back'.

questions.question: Components of biliary tract include:

options.text: Pancreas, cystic duct, common hepatic duct
Hepatic duct, common bile duct, cystic duct
Common bile duct, portal vein, hepatic artery

questions.explanation: The biliary tract transports bile. It includes the hepatic ducts, cystic duct (from gallbladder), and common bile duct.
questions.hint: Exclude organs like the spleen or pancreas tissue itself.

questions.question: You are teaching a patient about the use of a respiratory inhaler. Which action by the patient indicate need for further teaching?

options.text: Removes the cap and shakes the inhaler well before use.
Presses the canister down with his finger as he breathes in.
Inhales the mist and quickly exhales.
Waits 1 to 2 minutes between puffs if more than one puff has been prescribed.

questions.explanation: Patients must hold their breath for ~10 seconds after inhalation to allow the drug to settle. Quickly exhaling expels the medication.
questions.hint: The medication needs time to settle in the lungs.

questions.question: The effective management of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) includes:

options.text: Transfusion with frozen, anticoagulants, immunosuppressive drugs

questions.explanation: ITP is autoimmune. Treatment suppresses the immune system (Corticosteroids) and removes the site of destruction (Splenectomy).
questions.hint: It's an immune problem, so suppress the immunity.

questions.question: You suspect that a patient might be having a urinary tract infection (UTI). Which statement by the patient suggests that a UTI is likely?

options.text: "I go hours without the urge to pee."

questions.explanation: Dysuria (burning on urination) is a hallmark symptom of UTI.
questions.hint: Pain during function is a sign of infection.

questions.question: The key characteristic of pleural membrane inflammation to look out for is:

options.text: Central retro-sternal pain worsened by deep breathing
Central chest discomfort worsened by deep breath
Axillary stabbing pain worsened by deep breathing
Retro-sternal stabbing pain worsened on lying in Fowler's position

questions.explanation: Pleuritic pain is sharp, knife-like, often lateral/axillary, and worsens with inspiration (breathing in).
questions.hint: It hurts when the lungs expand and rub against the inflamed lining.

questions.question: Renal surgery is a very delicate procedure that can easily complicate to observable signs of:
questions.explanation: Kidneys are highly vascular. Hemorrhage leading to hypovolemic shock is the major post-op risk.
questions.hint: Kidneys receive 25% of cardiac output.

questions.question: Joint swelling in rheumatoid arthritis is easily diagnosed and suspected to be due to:
questions.explanation: RA causes synovitis and effusion (fluid accumulation), creating boggy swelling.
questions.hint: It's soft and boggy, not hard bone.

questions.question: Arrange the correct sequence of instrument processing for infection control:
questions.explanation: Decontamination first to make items safe to handle, then cleaning to remove organic matter, then sterilization.
questions.hint: Make it safe to touch -> Clean it -> Kill everything.

questions.question: You are assessing a patient in a surgical unit. Which of the following should you document as subjective data?
questions.explanation: Subjective data is what the patient feels or says (symptoms). Objective data is observed or measured (signs).
questions.hint: What the Subject says.

questions.question: The common malignant tumor of the bone is:
questions.explanation: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. Osteochondroma is benign.
questions.hint: 'Osteo' means bone, 'sarcoma' means malignant connective tissue tumor.

questions.question: You are preparing to test the visual acuity of a client using a Snellen chart. Which procedure is accurate?

options.text: Both eyes are assessed together, followed by the assessment of the right and then the left eye.
The right eye is tested followed by the left eye, and then both eyes are tested.
The client is asked to stand at a distance of 40ft. from the chart.
The client is asked to stand 40ft away to read a 200ft line.

questions.explanation: Test each eye individually first, then together. Standard distance is 20 feet (6 meters).
questions.hint: One at a time, then together.

questions.question: Upon prostate cancer diagnosis, which test is used to monitor the progression of this disease?
questions.explanation: PSA is a tumor marker for prostate cancer. Rising levels indicate progression or recurrence.
questions.hint: The name of the antigen tells you the organ.

questions.question: The major autonomic control center within the central nervous system that acts as the body's smart coordinating centre is:
questions.explanation: The hypothalamus regulates the Autonomic Nervous System and homeostasis.
questions.hint: It controls hunger, thirst, and temperature.

questions.question: During the cell cycle, the amount of DNA doubles during:
questions.explanation: DNA replication occurs in the Synthesis (S) phase of Interphase.
questions.hint: S stands for Synthesis (of DNA).

questions.question: During physical examination, the intraperitoneal organs that can be palpated include:
questions.explanation: The liver edge and sometimes the spleen (if enlarged) are palpable. The stomach can be palpable if distended or has a mass. Small intestines (ileum) are generally not palpable.
questions.hint: Think of the solid organs in the upper abdomen.

questions.question: To institute appropriate isolation precautions, as a nurse you must first know the:
questions.explanation: Isolation type (Contact, Droplet, Airborne) is dictated by HOW the germ spreads (transmission mode).
questions.hint: How does it travel from person to person?

questions.question: When bathing a patient's extremities, the nurse should use long, firm strokes from the distal to the proximal areas. This technique:

options.text: Provides an opportunity for skin assessment.
Avoids undue strain on the nurse.

questions.explanation: Washing distal to proximal follows venous flow back to the heart, promoting return.
questions.hint: Help the blood get back to the heart.

questions.question: For a patient in a coma due to head injury to be admitted in intensive care unit, you should certify that the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is:

options.text: Below six and eyes open spontaneously
The GCS is 6 and respiration rate is less than 8 breaths/min.
The GCS is below 3, and response to pain is by extension
GCS is 10 and verbal response is spontaneous

questions.explanation: A GCS < 8 usually requires intubation and ICU care.
questions.hint: Less than 8, intubate.

questions.question: Arrange the 5 steps of the Nursing Process in the correct sequential order:
questions.explanation: The nursing process follows the acronym ADPIE: Assessment, Diagnosis, Planning, Implementation, Evaluation.
questions.hint: Remember ADPIE.

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly describe the pharmacology of Furosemide? (Select all that apply)

options.text: It is classified as a Loop Diuretic.
It inhibits the sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter in the Loop of Henle.
It promotes reabsorption of sodium and water.
A common side effect is hyperkalemia.
A specific side effect includes hypokalemia.

questions.explanation: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that blocks Na/K/Cl reabsorption in the Loop of Henle, causing diuresis and potassium loss (hypokalemia).
questions.hint: It flushes out fluid and potassium.

questions.question: Which of the following are signs of overtreatment (hyperthyroidism) in a patient being treated for hypothyroidism? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Overtreatment causes metabolic acceleration: high heart rate, weight loss, heat intolerance, and anxiety.
questions.hint: Think of the body engine running too fast.

questions.question: You are giving a health talk on Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). Which emergency interventions would you highlight? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Fluid resuscitation with IV Normal Saline

questions.explanation: Treatment involves hydration, insulin to stop ketone production, and replacing potassium (which drops as insulin pushes it into cells).
questions.hint: Fluids, Insulin, Potassium.

questions.question: Which of the following are major complications of pneumonia that can lead to death? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Pneumonia kills via respiratory failure (lung collapse/filling) or sepsis (infection spreading to blood).
questions.hint: Lung failure and systemic infection.

questions.question: Which 'red flags' indicate a diagnosis of menorrhagia? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Soaking through sanitary pads every hour for several hours
Menstrual bleeding lasting longer than 7 days
Passage of blood clots larger than a quarter

questions.explanation: Menorrhagia is defined by heavy prolonged bleeding (>7 days) or excessive volume (soaking pads hourly, large clots).
questions.hint: Too much volume, too long duration.

questions.question: Which home remedies would you prescribe for ear wax blockage removal? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Use of cotton buds (Q-tips) to clean the canal
Instilling drops of baby oil or mineral oil

questions.explanation: Oil and peroxide soften wax; irrigation flushes it out. Cotton buds push wax deeper and are contraindicated.
questions.hint: Soften it, don't push it.

questions.question: Which factors should be considered when selecting a route for drug administration? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Condition of the patient (consciousness, ability to swallow)
Properties of the drug (e.g., destroyed by gastric acid)

questions.explanation: Route depends on urgency (IV vs PO), patient ability (unconscious?), and drug chemistry (first-pass effect).
questions.hint: Can they swallow? Do they need it NOW?

questions.question: Case Study: Miss V, 25 years old, has a temporal brain tumor and is scheduled for a craniotomy. Based on her condition, which of the following nursing interventions and assessments are appropriate? (Select all that apply)

richContent.content:
Clinical Scenario

Miss V, 25, diagnosed with a temporal lobe tumor. Condition deteriorating. Scheduled for Craniotomy.

options.text: Monitor for receptive aphasia and memory deficits (temporal lobe signs)
Administer corticosteroids (Dexamethasone) pre-operatively to reduce cerebral edema
Keep the head of bed flat (0 degrees) post-operatively
Monitor for 'halo sign' on dressings to detect CSF leakage
Position the patient on the operative side post-operatively

questions.explanation: Appropriate care: Monitor temporal signs (speech/memory), give steroids for edema, elevate head 30 degrees (NOT flat) to lower ICP, check for CSF leak, and position on NON-operative side to prevent pressure on the wound.
questions.hint: Think about ICP management and protecting the surgical site.
